ranked_diseases.explanation: Chronic oral candidiasis is a hallmark feature of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, which often presents with persistent and recurrent fungal infections of the skin, nails, and mucous membranes.
This condition often presents with chronic candidiasis, along with other autoimmune symptoms, indicating possible immune system dysregulation. It commonly starts in childhood or adolescence.
Hyper-IgE syndrome, while primarily known for recurrent skin and lung infections, can also present with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis due to immune system irregularities.
Patients with SCID often have opportunistic infections including chronic candidiasis due to severely impaired immune function.
Though more commonly associated with congenital anomalies, DiGeorge Syndrome also presents with immune deficiency, predisposing individuals to chronic infections including candidiasis.
